awd_titl_txt: Conference: 4th NeuroNex Investigator Meeting: Beyond Neurons
awd_abstract_narration:
The National Science Foundation NeuroNex network is a community of research teams that work on the leading edge of inventing and applying to foundational question in neuroscience diverse tools, techniques, software, animal models, behavioral and computational analysis, hardware development, systems biology, and many other areas of biological and theoretical research. NeuroNex investigators meet periodically to provide updates on their progress, collect feedback on experiments and results, and share ideas on timely topics in science and the practice of team science. These meetings are invaluable opportunities for NeuroNex investigators to network with other researchers and to form new collaborations and lines of inquiry that are possible only with interdisciplinary expertise and shared effort and resources. The theme of this NeuroNex Investigator Meeting, “Beyond Neurons,” is designed to stimulate creativity and generate ideas for the future of NeuroNex research. Through a series of progressive, interactive workshops, NeuroNex researchers are encouraged to consider how their advancements can be applied to challenges faced by other NeuroNex groups, to cell types other than neurons, to efforts beyond biology, and how they can impact on society beyond scientific research. The ideas generated through this process will identify emergent themes and inspire future research directions.  NeuroNex trainees (undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers) are key participants in these meetings and have the opportunity to present their work via a Poster Session attended by present and potential future national and internatinonal colleagues and mentors, and funding agency officials. 

The NeuroNex community has created valuable advancements in a variety of research areas. NeuroNex Investigator Meetings provide an opportunity for researchers to update their colleagues on their progress and to inspire them to ask and pursue answers to questions that require new models, techniques, tool invention and development, computation, and other paths of inquiry that are only possible through collaboration with other researchers. The meeting schedule includes time for participants to network with colleagues, a Poster Session that  allows each group to present an overview of their NeuroNex project and for trainees to share their research results, two talks from scientists external to the NeuroNex network whose work is especially relevant to the theme of the meeting and several workshop sessions focused on the theme of this NeuroNex Investigator Meeting, “Beyond Neurons.” This theme was chosen to challenge NeuroNex investigators to consider how they can apply their findings, models, tools, and other advancements to research questions in “Beyond Your Bench,” “Beyond Neurons,” “Into the Bioeconomy” and “Beyond Biology.” Through a series of Workshops, researchers consider each of these avenues of broader impact and, with subgroups of colleagues, identify the most interesting potential future directions as well as current challenges to pursuing those avenues. Ideas generated by each subgroup contribute to the meeting’s exercise of collectively identifying emergent themes and priorities for future research. Post-meeting discussions among members of the NeuroNex community will refine the visioning developed during the meeting. A direct, tangible outcome of the meeting is a White Paper summarizing the themes and priorities developed during the meeting. the White Paper will be broadly accessible through the public neuronex.org website.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The fourth NeuroNex Investigator Meeting: Beyond Neurons was held November 16-17, 2022, in San Diego, California. This conference convened leaders in the scientific community including: recipients of NeuroNex funding, program officers and other funding agency representatives, and special guests. We provided a platform for two Keynote Speakers working on topics adjacent to, but not embedded in, neuroscience, and facilitated conversation and networking via a Poster Session (that was later expanded into an Online Archive).   

The conference offered the first opportunity in three years for the NeuroNex community to gather in-person, and approximately 175 people attended the meeting. We leveraged this energetic and focused expertise to measure the opinion of the field via four interactive Workshops. Workshop I: Beyond Your Bench challenged participants to consider their research findings, tools, and resources and how they could collaborate with others to address research questions that would not be possible to pursue as individuals. Workshop II: Beyond Neurons asked the same groups how their findings, tools, and resources could be applied to study biological systems other than neurons. Workshop III: Into the Bioeconomy catalyzed the discussion of how existing and future progress on NeuroNex projects could contribute to the bioeconomy in new and creative ways. Workshop IV: Beyond Biology focused participants on imagining ways their findings, tools, and resources could benefit the world outside of biology.

Each of 16 Workshop groups was guided by a scientist Facilitator, and the ideas generated were methodically collected and considered by the group. After each session, all groups submitted their favorite ideas for collective analysis. Nine categories of ideas in three key themes emerged from these favorite ideas: New Knowledge (Computation/Modeling, Basic Biology, Comparative Analysis), New Methods (Tools/Methods, Timescale, Imaging), and New Field (Community, Training, Translation/Outreach).

 

Intellectual Merit

These Workshops showed agreement from neuroscientists at all career levels that it is time to move past a myopic focus exclusively on neurons if we are to understand behavior. This consensus -- from scientific experts without a clear, immediate benefit -- further spurred our decision to create a Center for the Embodied Brain at Brown University. This Center will be a knowledge and resource hub for the entire scientific community and will be the home for a new focus on the non-neural systems that create behavior. Key activities will include: creating computational models of the activities of non-neural contributors to behavior (e.g., astrocytes, immune system, endocrine system, gut) and adding those contributors to existing computational models of neural activity, building and/or modifying tools and techniques to study non-neural systems, and hosting workshops for scientific thought leaders to collectively decide on the vocabulary and needs for this new Field.

 

Broader Impact

The impact of the Beyond Neurons conference extended beyond the two-day meeting. Immediately following the event, the conference program manager, co-PI Dr. Justine Allen, worked with the NeuroNex web developer to create a digital archive of the posters presented in person. This allowed the findings from participating researchers to be communicated to a broader audience over a longer period of time (i.e., the Internet, indefinitely) to further spread knowledge and the potential for collaboration.

The Beyond Neurons conference collected a consensus from neuroscientists on the next most important directions for our study of the systems that contribute to behavior. This consensus, and our decision to create a Center for the Embodied Brain at Brown University, will have far-reaching impacts. Better understanding the multiple information-collecting and -processing systems that drive behavior will allow us to identify targets for therapies and treatments of disease (e.g., Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, ALS, schizophrenia, depression, etc.). There has been some progress in the study of non-neural systems (e.g., glia gate memory, immune cells regulate pain, and the microbiome impacts reward-seeking and economic behavior), but the field lacks focus. We can provide that focus, support, and vocabulary via our Center for the Embodied Brain, and impact science and medicine far into the future.
